Pour la petite histoire, ce fut extrêmement compliqué d'acheter nos billets car par 2 fois, j'ai reçu un mail annulant automatiquement ma réservation au motif que les 2 cartes bancaires que j'avais utilisées (carte visa crédit puis carte visa débit) étaient susceptibles d'avoir été utilisées frauduleusement, ce qui n'était bien sûr pas le cas. 

Pour résumer, j'ai été obligé quasiment d'utiliser une voie contestable moralement, mais quasiment nécessaire. Ça nous a coûté environ 500$ pour faire Panama - Cartagena, avec 2 adultes, 1 chien et l'obtention du papier du psychologue. Un autre couple de français a fait la même chose que nous sur le même vol, et un allemand avait fait pareil la semaine d'avant. 
Nous restons sur une très mauvaise impression du Panama, dommage. 

Bon courage pour les suivants, car il vous en faudra. N'hésitez pas à me faire un retour sur notre insta globtrailers

name: Roadside cafe
description: Super cheap but delicious roadside cafe just North West of David. Nice to find somewhere more affordable in Panama!

name: Hotel Ana Mary
description: Decent hotel with parking out front. Rooms have AC and hot showers. Good wifi. Totally acceptable option if the others in town are full (which was our case).

name: posas in the jungle
description:
beautiful rock formations „pools“ in the jungle- nothing else only some locals 
The road is 4x4 but nothing difficult- maybe rainy season is taffy 
no signal (but the sky is clear to the north iykyk) lil shade and nice breeze 
The „parking lot“ is a aprox 4 rigs bearable spot- than a short „staircase“ to the water level 
it is (howler monkey) jungle so proceed with caution (we saw tarantulas and night creatures are on the move)

name: bahia life
description:
super calm beach spot on the way to Brujas
the camp is under the trees directly behind the shoreline - some fishermen nearby 
nice 4x4 to get here- extreme steep curves but the road was in very good condition
no services
no mosquitoes 
no rocks in the water 
no fee

name: Water tap in centro de convenciones
description: A water tap with a lot of pressure. Ask security at the convention center before filling the tank. They say it is potable

name: Water Tap potable
description: Water tap in the El Rey supermarket parking, it is next to the veterinarian. You can drink the water without problems. Ask the maintenance people (generally they are not there)

name: Public riverside
description: Nice place town the road next to river. Locals told it is public place so camping is ok, also 1-3 campers could fit here.

name: Veterinaria K-Nino -Chanis
description:
An amazing vet. The staff is extremely helpful. They will do all the paperwork that you need when you are leaving Panama to go to Colombia.  We are coming back in three days to get the completed paperwork. We don’t have to make any other stops. 
The vet listens and is extremely thorough. 
It is upstairs in the shopping plaza. 
Hours 8-5 Monday-Saturday

name: Shipping Process Panama --> Colombia with Car and Dog
description:
Passage from Panama to Colombia with 1 vehicle and 1 dog

Be aware that the whole process takes time (around 15 days).

 1/ PANAMA:

 1-1/ VEHICLE.

 - it is much easier to use the services of a freight forwarder, who takes care of all the administrative procedures on both sides.  Especially if you don't know Spanish.

 - for our part, we made contact several weeks before (even if sometimes it's hard to plan to know when we will arrive in Panama City when we are in road trip mode) with the Overland Ambassy company, in the person of the  very friendly and competent Alejandro.  He is bilingual in Spanish/English.  He can be reached by WhatsApp at +50767800065.

 Check with him the availability of the ships to reserve a place (we pay a deposit of 150 USD by bank transfer, but we can move the date free of charge if necessary).

 You will be added to a Whatsapp group, along with other travelers who will be traveling on the same day as you, so that Alejandro can give you all the information.

 For containers, there are departures approximately every week.  For the Roro, it is less frequent.
 I'm going to tell you about the container procedure, for which we paid around 2,200 USD all inclusive.  It has the enormous advantage of being completely secure (no theft possible because the container is sealed in front of us) and its cost is twice as expensive as Roro (more than 4,000 USD).

Only drawback: the maximum height of the vehicle must be 2m57.  You can adjust the tire pressure if necessary to gain precious centimeters... On the other hand, for a large motorhome in a flat rack, the prices are more around 8,000 USD for example.

 - you will receive by email 2 pdf files explaining the steps to take on both sides.

 - for the police inspection, it must be done between 5 days and 3 days before the planned loading date.  Do not underestimate that the day will be tiring with a lot of waiting.  Do not be afraid of the neighborhood where the inspection is carried out, even if it is not very inviting.  You can, however, sleep the day before at the Ioverlander point located opposite the police which is on the other side of the street, where you will return in the AM: it's safe!

 Come very early in the morning (at least 1 hour / 1 hour 30 minutes before the recommended time) so as not to wait too long, even if you will never be the first).
 Park in the small street opposite the Police gate: don't be afraid, it's going well!

Join the people already waiting on the sidewalk (they are probably car exporters, they come here very often and can explain to you), and they will tell you that you are the Xth.  You are asked to come in pants and a long-sleeved top, for some reason...

 Then the gate opens and you are given a small piece of paper with your number (the Xth).  You will need to present the requested papers (2 bundles of photocopies and the originals) when you are called.

 If the TIP made at the border when entering the country contains an error (this was our case), quickly go to the customs offices (see on Ioverlander Adouana: it's about 30 minutes away) and have the TIP modified,  before returning.  You have to be back before 10 a.m. maximum!

 Then you wait again.  Then, a police officer comes to check the chassis numbers (VIN) and engine numbers on your vehicle.

 Afterwards, you have to come back in the afternoon, to a separate but very close place, on the other side of the street, to collect the paper needed for the rest (expect a significant wait - 3 hours for us).
 Use the Ioverlander application to find these places (activate the right filters).

 - Once the precious sesame has been collected, immediately go to the Overland Embassy agency, about 30 minutes by car.

Do the paperwork with Alejandro and his team (they can make photocopies if necessary) and pay the fees of around 1,000 USD (preferably in cash, because it is cheaper despite the withdrawal commissions than paying 5% in credit card)  .  That's all!

 You then have free access for 2 days if you want to the agency's small campsite, which allows you to park in a secure place near other travelers, and to benefit from a shared mobile home with showers, toilets,  kitchen, washing machine, wifi, etc... Very practical!
 If you want to stay longer, you will have to pay a little extra.

 - clean your vehicle thoroughly so as not to have any problems with Customs later.

 - prepare your belongings in luggage, so that you can last during 15 days.  Keep all your papers (especially the TIP).

 - On the D-day of loading, we meet either early in the morning at this campsite or at Colon (north, 1 hour drive) and we follow each other in a convoy to reach the loading location  near the port of Colon.
 Highway costs are covered by Overland Embassy.

 The vehicles are then mounted on a tow truck and loaded into a container.  We disconnect the battery.  It is interesting to buy moisture absorbers to put in the vehicle.  We lock it and keep the key with us.

 Then the container is closed and sealed (note the seal number).  Note the container number for tracking.  A stamp is placed on the vehicle owner's passport signifying that the vehicle is released from Panama.
 Finally, we are taken back by shuttle free of charge to the Panama City agency.

- now you will be able to organize your almost 2 weeks of waiting.  You can do as you wish: stay in Panama to visit or go to Cartagena (subject to an important point developed in the next paragraph).
 It's up to you to book hotel or Airbnb rooms...


 1-2/ PLANE.

 I will only talk about plane, but it is also possible to take a boat which takes several days at sea. The price is higher than the plane, but it must include meals.  Up to you.

 - there are 3 airlines: Copa Airlines (the main one, but the most expensive), Avianca (no direct flight to Cartagena) and Wingo.  The first 2 depart from Tocumen International Airport (to the East) and the last leaves from Pacifico (to the West).

 It is very important to see with Alejandro when you can legally depart from Panama, as some agents at the airport counter require proof of departure from Colombia to another country (plane ticket).  But for us traveling by vehicle, this is not possible.
 You must provide the TIP, passport stamp and container tracking.  But sometimes that's not enough.  Some agents require that the departure of the vehicle by sea takes place within a maximum of 2 days of our departure by plane.
 Alejandro will explain to you what you need to do.  With Wingo for our part, we had to fight 1h30 with 3 couples in the same situation and call Alejandro by phone).
 It took some sleight of hand on the tracking site for them to finally agree to give us our boarding passes.

 - Wingo is the cheapest company.
 But booking online with Wingo can be complicated because depending on your credit card, the reservation may either be impossible or canceled by email just a few hours after making it, under the pretext that they have a doubt about your bank card.  Check your email carefully!  There are other possible means of payment, such as paying at certain approved banks.

 Due to the fact that it is a low cost company, the prices are affordable.  Try to only take cabin baggage if you can, as checked baggage costs more.

1-3/ DOG OWNERS:

 1-31- The procedures are extremely complicated if you want to use the classic route, namely putting your dog in a cage, which will go in the hold of the plane.  For this, only the Copa company offers it, but it is an obstacle course, and I weigh my words carefully.

 COPA: all correspondence with them is done only by email.  They don't answer the phone and there's no point going to a counter because they can't do anything for us.  In the emails, everything is done in Spanish and they do not respond at all to specific questions and requests for explanations.  We are left to our own devices!  Not to mention that their response comes with a wait of at least half a day...

 In addition, prices depend on the size and weight of the animal (240 USD requested for our 16 kg dog!).
 You have to do it more than 1 week in advance (it would be even better if we had a lot more time before, but it's hard to predict) by filling out piles of stupid papers (never requested to come from Europe to  Canada) and sending photos of the dog in and out of its cage (they don't joke with the size of the cage which must allow the dog to stand up with a margin...).  The idea is that they lock a place for the dog on a morning flight between Monday and Thursday only.  This reservation takes quite a while, and until we have the answer, it is impossible for us to get a plane ticket for ourselves (and in the meantime, places are becoming rarer and more expensive  ).
 In addition, it is necessary to do a pre-check in the cargo area of ​​the airport the day before, hence significant Uber fees...
 And on the big day, you have to go back to drop off the dog, then go to the terminal which is not on site.  More Uber fees... Note that upon arrival in Colombia, there are fees of around 150 USD for unloading and customs clearance.
 In short, you understand, it's hell!  After 4 days, we gave up.

 1-32- SOLUTION FOUND:
 it may be morally questionable, but it actually works.

The trick is to consult a psychologist in Panama City in order to obtain an emotional dog certificate (a general practitioner cannot do this and you absolutely need the letterhead of a psychologist on the paper).  Basically, this means that we have a deep psychological need to travel with our dog because we are making this trip following a burn-out in France, and we need the dog in the cabin with us.

We therefore have to make the psychologist believe that we are very stressed, that the situation in Panama City is causing us a lot of worry because we cannot get our dog into the hold, that we do not have confidence in the  way that the employees will treat him in his cage, that as a result we have been sleeping very poorly for a few days, etc...
 For a consultation of 100 USD in cash, the psychologist has no difficulty in delivering the precious paper.  Rest assured, even if it seems like a large sum, it will be immediately paid for because with Wingo, emotional dogs are allowed in the cabin... for free!
 To find a psychologist, Google is your friend.  We consulted Doctor Edgard Agames, who can be reached by WhatsApp at +50767479449, but there are others!

 Please note that this document is valid for 1 year, and that it also allows access to places normally prohibited with "normal" dogs (such as public transport).  So keep this paper with you afterwards.

 Then simply book your plane tickets on the Wingo website, by selecting to add a dog (if you can't find one, use the free WhatsApp chat to communicate with an advisor who can do it for you)  .

 Depending on the size of the dog, it may be useful to reserve a seat with more foot room as even a large dog can in theory be accommodated.

1-33- At the same time, you must have a certificate of good health for the animal less than 10 days old (around 35 USD in the city) and go to MIDA in the city center to obtain an export certificate (10  USD): see my post on Ioverlander.  It's super fast: less than 1 hour.  These documents must be presented on the day of boarding.

 1-34- On the big day, take an Uber to reach Pacifico airport (less than 10 USD from the city center).  Present the emotional dog certificate and dog papers at the check-in counter, and voila!
 The flight lasts 1 hour 15 minutes.

 Upon arrival in Cartagena, you will need to complete import papers at the airport (approximately 25 USD).  For us, it was an official agent who approached us in the queue to leave the secure area.  It was quick.


 2/ COLOMBIA (Cartagena).

 2-1- WAIT

 - You will have time to visit this pretty city, but be careful, it is VERY hot.
 You must choose accommodation, if possible flexible enough to be able to add additional nights in the event of a delay (or change accommodation).
 For our part, we had counted on a D+15 recovery after loading in Panama, and it worked out well!

 Personally, we booked an Airbnb in the Manga district, not far from the center, offering good value for money and known for being safe.  We were not disappointed.

 Some opt to leave Panama City directly to Medellin or Bogota to visit other cities in the meantime, then they fly back to Cartagena to pick up their car...

 - you can watch the tracking of the container on the website given by Alejandro, just to see if it is late leaving Panama.

 But above all, you will receive information on a Whatsapp group created by Ana Rodriguez, who works with Alejandro, and who takes care of all the procedures upon arrival.  She only speaks in Spanish, and although very nice, she communicates little and it is sometimes a little complicated to understand what she says because of the inaccuracies of the translation applications, but it can be done.  Don't hesitate to ask questions...

 - take advantage of the wait to withdraw money in cash (approximately the equivalent of 1000 USD in local currency, the peso).  See on Ioverlander, the Davivienda bank in the historic center allows withdrawals of 2,000,000 pesos in one go, which reduces commission costs.  You can pay Ana by credit card, but it will cost you more.

2-2- Unloading.

 A few days after the arrival of the boat, unloading is carried out.  You will be informed on the Whatsapp group that you must present yourself at the port, still in pants and with a long-sleeved top.  You will check the condition and number of the container seal, then you take the car out of the container.  We need to check the condition (no damage for the 5 cars we had) and take photos of the 4 sides of the car as well as the VIN number to send to Ana.  Then you leave without your car.  It remains parked at the port, doors locked.  The keys are entrusted to a port employee.  There has never been a problem.

 2-3- TIP

 Approximately 2 working days later, customs will have produced the TIP.  For her part, Ana will have taken out SOAT insurance for you to be able to drive for 1 month in Colombia (the price is included in what you will pay her).  You will have an appointment in a restaurant not far from the port with an agent from the Ana company to sign the TIP.

 2.3- Payment and recovery of the vehicle.

 - The next day (or not far away), you will first meet at Ana's offices to pay her.  It is located south of the port, and you need to take an Uber because it is far and not easy to find.

 - Then head to the port, still in long clothes, to collect your vehicle.  A few signatures of papers, and it's over!!!  You are ready to attack South America.



 Hoping that the tutorial helps you in turn.  Don't hesitate to follow us on Insta (globtrailers) or on Facebook (Glob Trailers) or YouTube (lesglobtrailers), and give us feedback if it helped you!
--------
Passage du Panama en Colombie avec 1 véhicule et 1 chien 

Etre conscient que tout le processus prend du temps (environ 15 jours). 

1/ PANAMA: 

1-1/ VEHICULE. 

- il est nettement plus facile de passer par les services d'un transitaire, qui s'occupe de toutes les démarches administratives des 2 côtés. Surtout si vous ne maîtrisez pas l'espagnol. 

- pour notre part, on a pris contact plusieurs semaines avant (même si parfois, c'est dur de se projeter pour savoir quand on arrivera à Panama City quand on est en mode road trip) avec la société Overland Ambassy, en la personne du très sympathique et compétent Alejandro. Il est bilingue espagnol / anglais. On peut le joindre par WhatsApp au +50767800065. 

Voir avec lui les disponibilités des navires pour réserver une place (on paie un acompte de 150 USD par virement bancaire, mais on peut déplacer gratuitement la date si besoin). 

Vous serez ajouté sur un groupe Whatsapp, ainsi que les autres voyageurs qui vont voyager le même jour que vous, afin qu'Alejandro puisse vous donner toutes les informations. 

Pour les containers, il y a des départs toutes les semaines environ. Pour les Roro, c'est moins fréquent. 
Je vais vous parler de la procédure en container, pour laquelle nous avons payé environ 2.200 USD tout compris. Il présente l'énorme avantage d'être totalement sécurisé (pas de vol possible car le container est scellé devant nous) et son coût est 2 fois moins cher que pour du Roro (plus de 4.000 USD). 

Seul inconvénient: la hauteur maximum du véhicule doit être de 2m57. On peut jouer si besoin sur la pression des pneus pour gagner de précieux centimètres... En revanche, pour un gros camping-car dans un flat rack, les prix sont plutôt de l'ordre de 8.000 USD par exemple. 

- vous recevrez par mail 2 fichiers pdf vous expliquant les démarches à réaliser des 2 côtés. 

- pour l'inspection de police, elle est à faire entre 5 jours et 3 jours avant la date de chargement prévu. Ne pas sous-estimer que la journée sera fatigante avec beaucoup d'attente. Ne pas avoir peur du quartier où est réalisée l'inspection, même s'il est peu engageant. Vous pouvez en revanche dormir la veille sur le point Ioverlander se situant en face de la police qui est de l'autre côté de la rue, là où vous reviendrez l'AM: c'est safe! 

Venir très tôt le matin (au moins 1h / 1h30 avant l'heure recommandée) pour ne pas  trop attendre, même si vous ne serez jamais le premier). 
Garez-vous dans la petite rue qui est en face du portail de la Police: n'ayez pas peur, ça se passe bien! 

Rejoindre les gens qui attendent déjà sur le trottoir (ce sont sûrement des exportateurs de voiture, ils viennent ici très souvent et peuvent vous expliquer), et ils vous diront que vous êtes le Xème. Il est demandé de venir en pantalon et en vêtement haut à manches longues, pour une raison que j'ignore... 

Puis le portail s'ouvre et on vous donne un petit bout de papier avec votre numéro (le Xème). Vous devrez présenter les papiers demandés (2 liasses de photocopies et les originaux) quand on vous appellera. 

Si le TIP réalisé à la frontière en entrant dans le pays comporte une erreur (c'était notre cas), filez rapidement aux bureaux de douanes (voir sur Ioverlander Adouana: c'est à environ 30mn de route) et faites modifier le TIP, avant de revenir. Il faut être de retour avant 10 heures maximum! 

Puis vous attendez encore. Ensuite, un policier vient contrôler sur votre véhicule les numéros de châssis (VIN) et de moteur. 

Après, il faut revenir l'après-midi, dans un endroit distinct mais très proche, de l'autre côté de la rue, pour récupérer un papier nécessaire pour la suite (prévoir une attente conséquente - 3 heures pour nous). 
S'aider de l'application Ioverlander pour trouver ces endroits (activez les bons filtres). 

- Une fois le précieux sésame récupéré, se rendre dans la foulée à l'agence Overland Ambassy, à environ 30mn de voiture. 

Faire les papiers avec Alejandro et son équipe (ils peuvent faire les photocopies si besoin) et payez les frais d'environ 1.000 USD (de préférence en cash, car ça revient moins cher malgré les commissions de retrait que de payer 5% en CB). C'est tout! 

On a alors accès gratuitement pendant 2 jours si l'on veut au petit camping de l'agence, qui permet de se garer dans un endroit sécurisé auprès d'autres voyageurs, et de bénéficier d'un mobilhome en commun avec douches, toilettes, cuisine, lave-linge, wifi, etc... Très pratique!
Si vous voulez rester plus longtemps, il faudra payer un petit supplément. 

- bien nettoyer votre véhicule pour ne pas avoir de soucis avec les Douanes plus tard. 

- préparez vos affaires dans des bagages, pour pouvoir tenir pendant une quinzaine de jours. Gardez bien tous vos papiers (dont le TIP surtout). 

- Le jour J du chargement, on se donne rendez-vous soit tôt le matin au niveau de ce camping, soit au niveau de Colon (au nord à 1 heure de route) et on se suit en convoi pour rejoindre l'endroit de chargement près du port de Colon.
Les frais d'autoroute sont pris en charge par Overland Ambassy. 

Les véhicules sont alors montés sur une dépanneuse et chargés dans un container. On débranche la batterie. Il est intéressant d'acheter des absorbeurs d'humidité à mettre dans le véhicule. On ferme à clés et on garde la clé avec nous. 

Puis le container est fermé et scellé (noter le numéro du scellé). Notez le numéro du container pour le tracking. Un tampon est apposé sur le passeport du propriétaire du véhicule signifiant que le véhicule est libéré du Panama.
Enfin, on est ramenés en navette gratuitement à l'agence de Panama City. 

- maintenant, vous allez pouvoir organiser vos presques 2 semaines d'attente. Vous pouvez faire comme bon vous semble: rester au Panama pour visiter ou aller à Carthagène (sous réserve d'un point important développé dans le paragraphe suivant).
A vous de réserver des chambres d'hôtel ou d'Airbnb... 


1-2/ AVION. 

Je ne parlerai que d'avion, mais il est aussi possible de prendre un bateau qui met plusieurs jours de mer. Le tarif est plus élevé que l'avion, mais il doit comprendre les repas. A vous de voir. 

- il y a 3 compagnies aériennes: Copa Airlines (la principale, mais la plus chère), Avianca (pas de vol direct vers Carthagène) et Wingo. Les 2 premières partent de l'aéroport international de Tocumen (à l'Est) et la dernière part de Pacifico (à l'Ouest). 

Il est très important de voir avec Alejandro quand vous pouvez légalement partir du Panama, car certains agents au comptoir de l'aéroport exigent une preuve de départ de Colombie vers un autre pays (billet d'avion). Mais pour nous voyageurs en véhicule, ce n'est pas possible.
Il faut fournir le TIP, le tampon du passeport et le tracking du container. Mais parfois ça ne suffit pas. Certains agents exigent que le départ du véhicule par voie maritime ait lieu à maximum 2 jours de notre départ en avion.
Alejandro vous expliquera ce que vous devez faire. Avec Wingo pour notre part, on a dû batailler 1h30 à 3 couples dans le même cas et appeler Alejandro par téléphone). 
Il a fallu un tour de passe-passe sur le site du tracking pour qu'ils acceptent finalement de nous donner nos cartes d'embarquement. 

- Wingo est la compagnie la moins cher.
Mais la réservation par internet chez Wingo peut être compliquée car selon votre CB, la réservation peut être soit impossible, soit annulée par mail quelques heures seulement après l'avoir réalisée, sous pretexte qu'ils ont un doute sur votre carte bancaire. Vérifiez bien votre mail! Il y a d'autres moyens de paiement possibles, comme aller payer dans certaines banques agréés. 

Du fait qu'il s'agisse d'une compagnie low costs, les tarifs sont abordables. Essayez de prendre uniquement des bagages cabines si vous le pouvez, car un bagage en soute coûte plus cher.



1-3/  PROPRIETAIRES DE CHIENS: 

1-31- Les démarches sont extrêmement compliquées si vous voulez utiliser la voie classique, à savoir mettre votre chien dans une cage, laquelle ira en soute de l'avion. Pour cela, seule la compagnie Copa le propose, mais c'est le parcours du combattant, et je pèse mes mots. 

COPA: toute correspondance avec eux se fait uniquement par mail. Ils ne répondent pas par téléphone et il est inutile d'aller à un guichet car ils ne peuvent rien faire pour nous. Dans les mails, tout se fait en espagnol et ils ne répondent pas du tout aux questions précises et aux demandes d'explication. On est livrés à nous-mêmes! Sans parler que leur réponse se fait avec une attente d'au moins une demi-journée... 

De plus, les tarifs dépendent de la taille et du poids de l'animal (240 USD demandés pour notre chien de 16 Kg !).
Il faut s'y prendre plus d'1 semaine avant (ce serait encore mieux si on avait beaucoup plus de temps avant, mais c'est dur à prévoir) en remplissant des tas de papiers débiles (jamais demandés pour venir d'Europe au Canada) et en envoyant des photos du chien dans et en dehors de sa cage (ils ne plaisantent pas avec la taille de la cage qui doit permettre au chien de tenir debout avec une marge...). L'idée est qu'ils verrouillent une place pour le chien sur un vol du matin entre lundi et jeudi uniquement. Cette réservation prend pas mal de temps, et tant qu'on n'a pas la réponse, impossible pour nous de prendre un billet d'avion pour nous-mêmes (et pendant ce temps là, les places se font plus rares et plus chères).
De plus, il est nécessaire de faire un pré-check en zone cargo de l'aéroport la veille, d'où des frais d'Uber consequents...
Et le jour J, il faut y retourner pour déposer le chien, puis aller à l'aérogare qui n'est pas sur place. Encore des frais d'Uber... A noter qu'à l'arrivée en Colombie, il y a des frais d'environ 150 USD pour le déchargement et le dédouanement.
Bref, vous avez compris, c'est l'enfer! Au bout de 4 jours, on a abandonné. 

1-32- SOLUTION TROUVÉE: 
elle peut être discutable sur le plan de la morale, mais elle fonctionne réellement. 

L'astuce est d'aller consulter un psychologue à Panama City afin d'obtenir un certificat de chien émotionnel (un medecin generaliste ne peut pas le faire et il faut absolument l'en-tête d'un psychologue sur le papier). En gros, ça veut dire qu'on a un profond besoin psychologique de voyager avec notre chien car on fait ce voyage suite à un burn-out en France, et qu'on a besoin du chien dans la cabine auprès de nous. 

Il faut donc faire croire au psy qu'on est très stressés, que la situation à Panama City nous engendre beaucoup d'inquiétudes car on n'arrive pas à faire passer notre chien en soute, qu'on n'a pas confiance dans la manière que les employés vont le traiter dans sa cage, que du coup on dort très mal depuis quelques jours, etc...
Moyennant une consultation de 100 USD en cash, le psy ne fait aucune difficulté à délivrer le précieux papier. Rassurez-vous, même si ça paraît être une grosse somme, elle sera immédiatement amortie car avec Wingo, les chiens émotionnels sont autorisés en cabine... gratuitement!
Pour trouver un psy, Google est votre ami. On a consulté le Docteur Edgard Agames joignable par WhatsApp au +50767479449, mais il y en a d'autres! 

A noter que ce papier est valable 1 an, et qu'il permet aussi d'avoir accès à des lieux normalement interdits avec des chiens "normaux" (comme des transports en commun). Gardez donc bien ce papier avec vous par la suite. 

Il suffit ensuite de réserver vos billets d'avion sur le site internet de Wingo, en sélectionnant l'ajout d'un chien (si vous ne trouvez pas, utilisez le tchat whatsapp gratuit pour communiquer avec un conseiller qui pourra le faire pour vous). 

Selon la taille du chien, il peut être utile de réserver un siège offrant une plus grande place au niveau des pieds car même un gros chien peut en théorie être accepté. 


1-33- Parallèlement à ça, il faut avoir un certificat de bonne santé de l'animal datant de moins de 10 jours (environ 35 USD en ville) et aller au MIDA dans le centre ville pour obtenir un certificat d'exportation (10 USD): voir mon post sur Ioverlander. C'est hyper rapide: moins d'1 heure. Ces documents seront à présenter le jour de l'embarquement. 

1-34-  Le jour J, prendre un Uber pour rejoindre l'aéroport Pacifico (moins de 10 USD depuis le centre-ville). Présenter le certificat de chien émotionnel et les papiers du chien au comptoir d'enregistrement, et le tour est joué!
Le vol dure 1h15. 

A l'arrivée à Carthagène, vous devrez faire les papiers d'importation à l'aéroport (25 USD environ). Pour nous, c'est un agent officiel qui nous a abordé dans la queue pour sortir de la zone sécurisée. C'était rapide.


2/ COLOMBIE (Carthagène). 

2-1- ATTENTE 

- Vous allez avoir du temps pour visiter cette jolie ville, mais attention, il y fait TRÈS chaud. 
Vous devez prendre un hébergement, si possible assez souple pour pouvoir rajouter des nuits supplementaires en cas de retard (ou changer d'hébergement).
Pour notre part, on avait misé sur une récupération J+15 après le chargement au Panama, et c'est tombé bien! 

Personnellement, on a réservé un Airbnb dans le quartier Manga, pas loin du centre, offrant un bon rapport qualité/ prix et réputé pour être safe. On n'a pas été déçu. 

Certains optent pour partir de Panama City en allant directement à Medellin ou Bogota afin de visiter d'autres villes en attendant, puis ils reviennent en avion à Carthagène pour récupérer leur voiture... 

- vous pourrez regarder le tracking du container sur le site internet donné par Alejandro, histoire de voir si ca prend du retard au départ de Panama. 

Mais surtout, vous recevrez des informations sur un groupe Whatsapp créé par Ana Rodriguez, qui travaille avec Alejandro, et qui s'occupe de toutes les démarches à l'arrivée. Elle ne parle qu'en Espagnol, et bien que très gentille, elle communique peu et il est parfois un peu compliqué de comprendre ce qu'elle dit à cause des imprecisions des applications de traduction, mais ça se fait. Il ne faut pas hésiter à lui poser des questions... 

- profitez de l'attente pour aller retirer de l'argent en cash (environ l'équivalent de 1000 USD en monnaie locale, le peso). Voir sur Ioverlander, la banque Davivienda du centre historique permet des retraits de 2.000.000 de pesos en une fois, ce qui permet de réduire les frais de commissions. Vous pouvez payer Ana en CB, mais ça vous coûtera plus cher. 

2-2- Déchargement. 

Quelques jours après l'arrivée du bateau, le déchargement est réalisé. Vous serez informés sur le groupe Whatsapp qu'il faut vous présenter au port, toujours en pantalon et avec un vêtement haut à manches longues. Vous allez vérifier l'état et le numero du scellé du container, puis vous sortez la voiture du container. Il faut vérifier l'état (aucun dommage pour les 5 voitures qu'on était) et faire des photos des 4 faces de la voitures ainsi que du numéro de VIN pour envoyer à Ana. Puis vous repartez sans votre voiture. Celle-ci reste garée au port, portes verrouillées à cle. Les clés sont confiées à un employé du port. Il n'y a jamais eu de problème. 

2-3- TIP 

Environ 2 jours ouvrés plus tard, la douane aura produit le TIP. De son côté, Ana aura souscrit pour vous une assurance SOAT pour pouvoir conduire durant 1 mois en Colombie (le prix est compris dans ce que vous lui paierez). Vous aurez RDV dans un restaurant pas loin du port avec un agent de la société d'ana pour signer le TIP. 

2.3- Paiement et récupération du véhicule. 

- Le lendemain (ou pas loin), vous aurez RDV d'abord aux bureaux d'Ana pour la payer. Ça se situe au Sud du port, et il est nécessaire de prendre un Uber car c'est loin et pas facile à trouver. 

- Puis direction le port, toujours en tenue longue, pour récupérer votre véhicule. Quelques signatures de papiers, et c'est fini!!! Vous êtes prêts à attaquer l'Amérique du Sud.

En espérant que le tutoriel vous aide à votre tour. N'hésitez pas à nous suivre sur Insta (globtrailers) ou sur Facebook (Glob Trailers) ou YouTube (lesglobtrailers), et à nous faire un retour si ça vous a aidé!

name: Cerro Iguana Pull Out
description: This is a great spot on the side of the road to Cerro Iguana. The road is steep, but doable in a two wheel drive. The spot allows for views of the city below. Quiet spot with only a few cars passing in the night. Pretty level for our 6.5m truck. The trailhead to Cerro Iguana is maybe a mile beyond here.

name: Estacionamento Público Caldera - Marcando Territórios
description:
Public parking next to the Caldera football field.  Quiet place, excellent for a night.  There are bathrooms nearby, water taps. Public WiFi.There are also some electricity sockets, but we didn't use them, you may need to ask for permission.  At dusk, city residents come to play sports.  Very friendly and attentive people.

Estacionamento público ao lado do campo de futebol de Caldera. Lugar silencioso, excelente para uma noite. Há banheiros próximos, torneiras de água. Wifi publico.Há também algumas tomadas de eletricidade, mas não fizemos uso, talvez seja necessário pedir permissão. No entardecer os moradores da cidade vem praticar esportes. Pessoas muito amigáveis e atenciosas.

name: Laboratorio y Servicio Diésel de Chiriqui
description: I fixed a problem with the injectors on a non-working day during the carnival. Very friendly and very good price. His name is Isidoro. He was very busy but he gave me priority! recommended

name: free showers in the Marina
description: beautiful free showers and toilets right next to the pool.. unfortunately not hot

name: good drinkable water
description: on the right side of the gate. Even with a hose and adapter for your own hose to make filling easier. Locals come here as well to get their water, because the quality is so good. And while you fill your containers, enjoy watching the Panama Chanel!

name: view point eclusas FREE
description: we parked here, there is a water tap we think it is potable. You can watch the ships passing by for free

name: Taller ADACOR chapisteria
description:
We had a problem with our skylight. The dome was torn off. ADACOR found us an alternative solution by manufacturing a dome and attaching it to the roof. Fast and efficient work
-------------
On a eu un souci avec notre lanterneau. Le dôme a été arraché. ADACOR nous a trouvé une solution de remplacement en fabriquant un dôme et en le fixant au toit. Travail rapide et efficace

name: Emilie
description: here you can store if, you want to go to the islands: 7 dollars a day for our car which is six fifty and pretty high. the ground is a bit lose so we don't recommend from more than 4 tons. Very friendly owner Emilie.

name: Bridge 10 t
description: This bridge is limited to 10 t. So big rigs should stay in the valley. Before this bridge you can turn around easily, but you can’t drive up the hill/mountain. The last possibility for big rigs to stay overnight is „Boquete free camp“ the wild camp spot a few km before.

name: Pinguino Café
description: Exceptional Italian restaurant. Delicious food and amazing setting. Great sundowner. Even iOverlander don’t accept restaurants anymore, here in the village is no other restaurant and this restaurant is great!

name: mirador pixvae
description: Great view of the sea, amazing sunset, no facilities. To get here is a paved but very steep road! No 4G reception.

name: Autoparabrisas Panama
description: We got a windshield replacement for our Chevrolet 2000 CK3500 Truck camper van within 2h. Somebody in the office speaks English. Fair pricing as far as we can tell.

name: Auto Partes Willy
description: Oil and oil filter exchange for 15$ plus the parts (for us oil and filter were an extra 48$). Very friendly, doesn't speak much but understands English. A few meters down the road towards Colon there are two more shops where you can get spare parts in case they don't have it.

name: Beach
description: Little spot to camp 2-3 tents in road loop next to beach under tree. Local visit it to see sun set. Little bit garbage aroud everywhere. Sand road, 4x4 needed.

name: Anita Pension
description:
Cheap and cheerful
$10 for a double room
Share bathrooms
WiFi
Owner is a lovely elderly gentleman who only speaks Spanish

name: Dry Express auto servicio
description:
Self-service laundry. $2.00 to wash / $2.50 to dry
---
Lavanderia com auto serviço. $2,00 para lavar / $2,50 para secar

name: Rainforest Discovery Center
description: Drive to the Rainforest Discovery Center. Pass the center another 100m. End of the road, start of the pipeline path. Small parking in the middle of the jungle. Camping is allowed. Only howler monkeys and you... No services, old toilet.

name: emilie parking
description:
we parked our car here for 3 nights, the first night we slept in the parking lot, it's a very organized place, with toilets, we felt safe, we left our car here for the others nights while we went to Bocas del Toro,  5$ per night and Emilie take you at the ferry station with her own car, very kind

highly recommend!!

name: Wild spot
description: really nice spot for overnight in vehicle, not bad for tents. Just is not too hide, but not to much people around is a quite area. the photo is from the main road. The river is clear. No Tigo Signal.

name: Under the bridge
description: nice spot under the bridge, you can go down by moto or bicycle but with vehicle there is a big space to leave it. clear water, good Tigo Signal

name: Free local Balneario
description:
perfect spot, free good river, almost empty on weekends evening and good shadows, also there is a fruit tree, called Caimito, its Delicious I left a photo. And with the leaves you can make tea. 

Good Tigo Signal.
If you are a rider, you can camp completely hide, just follow the path en the right side(below the small building), a few isolated places near the river.

Just follow the signals from the town, you'll love it.

name: Balneario Paso Caimito
description:
Nice free balneario just at 15min from las tablas. I slept 3 night in my tent here while I visit the carnaval, locals are so nice and welcoming 
Good Tigo Signal.
For more info check on Google maps this place.

name: Balneario el gringo
description: free but nice spot for 4x4, motos or bikes. A lot of locals on weekends.

name: Cascadas camping
description: For 5usd the people who manages the waterfalls give a place to put your tent.

name: Trailhead to La Silampa
description:
Here is the parking lot and the trailhead to La Silampa waterfall

beautiful natural pool, great hike about 3 km and about 1.5 hours each way, but the walk and the effort are worth it, a dream, a big pool and a few smaller ones, take a lot of water with you, there is no shade on the way, we have 5  $ paid for parking/entrance,

name: Taller Boli Jaen (alternator mechanic/revision)
description: Our Volkswagen Transporter alternator broke down in Costa Rica, and several mechanics had no clue wat to do. Got this place recommended by a local, they are specialized in alternator revisions. For 71 dollars they repaired our alternator in less than an hour! Great guys, super friendly.

name: Charco Lukas
description: A new campground without trees, good for Starlink. Hot shower, clean toilet which not always functional. The owner, Moises, is nice and helpful. WhatsApp 67-55-84-29.

name: Big quiet parking bay
description: quite a large bay on the side of a mountain road, totally accessible on 2 wheel drive. we spent a night here and no one asked any questions. very close to all the trails and view points in the area, you can get up and start your hike early. a lot of trash around sadly, we collected two full black bags to dispose of later but wasn't enough.

name: Water tap free
description:
Water tap... Water tap to fill the tank. We don't know if it's drinkable! but it looks very clean.

in Boquete there are many taps next to the river where you can get water without any problem, you can arrange the hose and the pressure is very good, you fill the tank very fast, the truth is that it is wonderful to get water in Boquete. we do not know if it is drinkable, we do not use it for drinking.

name: river xing(s)
description:
beautiful scenic road from San Jose to the Lagunas w/ heavy roads and river xings (60 cm + w/ rock soil)
overlanding fun for the whole family 
The first part is newly made
At the waterfall Chorrillito starts

name: la Floria de las flores.
description: beautiful  park with Gorgeous  flower. Walking distance from town

name: terpel gas station
description: water tap in gas station. we refined our water tank

name: Water filt
description: We round this place, in the intersection betwen the roads

name: Quiet and safe street
description:
We spent several nights here, right at the beginning of the street, very close to the parking lot of the Radison hotel which has security personnel all day and night. the street is quiet, there are several restaurants and it is better lit than the big parking lot in front of the soccer fields (this is right behind the fields). After trying several places in the city, we found this one to be the best.
---
pasamos aquí varias noches, justo al principio de la calle, muy cerca del parking del hotel Radison que tiene personal de seguridad todo el día y la noche. la calle es tranquila, hay varios restaurantes y está más iluminada que el parking grande frente a las canchas de fútbol ( esto es justo detrás de las canchas). Después de probar varios lugares de la ciudad, este nos pareció el mejor.

name: Restaurante New Hawaii
description: Very good and cheap Chinese Restaurant, Authentic food. A plate with fried rice with chicken for two Persons and a Coke only a 6.70!

name: Rain forest discovery center
description:
This is the actial rain forest discovery center parking lot. You buy your tickets here to hike the trails. The cost is stiff $30. 
At the fork back where yiu entered into discovery center, if you stay right you will get ro Pipe stone road parking and trailhead. It's  free to hike there. You can wild camp there too. Good cell signal

name: Delta Gas
description: This newly opened gas station is 10 km east of Portobelo and the only one in the area.  We did see another one near the end of the road to the east, but it was in rough shape.

name: Previo a playa estrella
description:
Place to park the motorhome, we spent the night here, it felt very safe and very peaceful. Next to the sea.
Lugar para estacionar el motorhome, nosotros pasamos la noche aquí, se siente muy seguro y muy tranquilo. Al lado del mar.

name: AutoStar - AdBlue/DEF and car parts
description: You can find here AdBlue/DEF and car parts for Mercedes.

name: DANGEROUS PART OF ROAD
description:
STOP HERE AND WALK THE TRAIL. The next part of this trail can be extremely dangerous for trucks with a lot of weight. 

There are currently two parts of the trail that are washed out more or less.

name: Trusty mechanic n a place to sleep
description:
We had some work done on our Sprinter.  Trusty local mechanic.  Father and son shop.  There is also a body workshop beside them.
They took care of us for 3 days.  We slept in our van, at the shop floor.  We got power, water and a washroom.  Nothing fancy but free and complimentary.
The shop does not look organized, but they know what they are doing.
Trusty mechanic shop.
WhatsApp contact: Ramiro (+507 6895-3322).
happy travels.

name: AF Car Performance
description:
MODERATOR NOT: Place added by owner and has not been Overlander verified.

We are a general mechanic and painting workshop, we have spaces for large trucks, we can help with whatever you need to continue your adventures

name: Puerto Carti
description:
I travel by bike and wanted to avoid the touristic sailing companies to go to Colombia. From Panama City the road just after El Llena is new but very steep. you need to be patient concerning the boat to Caledonia (Panama). I ve waited two days at the port and sleep there for free in front of the ticket office. Restaurant and simple shop opened from 7am to 5pm. Very safe.
to go to Colombia you need to go first to Caledonia (3 hours) then Puerto Obaldia (1,5 hour) and finally Carpugana en Colombia (45 minutes). Ask around, people will help you. Total coast less than 200 dollars with bicycle included.

name: “Emergency” aka heavens waiting room
description:
DO NOT GO HERE FOR MEDICAL EMERGENCIES. 

PLEASE. 

As an ex health care worker of emergency medicine : trauma. I had to urgently go here and had to yell for a doctor and be transported to Las Tablas by ambulance because I demanded it. 

They were going to send me home after a single bag of fluids because I was “stable” no doctor exam. No blood test. Nothing. I would have died if I didn’t yell for a real doctor. 

The paramedics from the ambulance asked more questions and did more of an exam Than every single person in this place. Please, do not go here. Take the 40-minute ride or ambulance to Las Tablas. The care you get there is efficient and free, including the ambulance ride.

name: Sea Cliff Wild Camping Ground
description: This a place where you can set your camping tents and have fun set your kitchen and it is very safe

name: Motoposada_el_rancho
description: A nice camping ground where you can stay just 4km away from panamerican highway 5$ per night per camping ,

name: MIDA — After health certificate
description:
Right by the last blue elevator are the doors to
VENTANILLA UNICA

You need a copy of the certificate of health one copy of the vaccinations

If you have no copy, go right next door (looking at the doors it's to the right) to the little tienda with no name. On the left there is a young man on a computer. He will enter you and your pet information online and give you a number plus make a copy of the health certificate. About 2.50 USD

Take that number and the copies to the VENTANILLA UNICA de comercio exterior. Give copies only. Pay $10
USD by card only. Wait. Get the official form.
I was told this is the last step.

name: Jmap
description: Gia provides safe storage for vehicles and has garage for motorcycles, also has accommodation as well, nice lady very friendly,  speaks great english,  +507 6659-8914 (Gias Whatsapp)

name: Parking next to the closed supermarket
description:
We slept 2 nights in this place and it was very quiet and safe.  There is a 24-hour Terpel station on the corner and there is a supermarket nearby.

Dormimos 2 noites neste local e foi bem tranquilo e seguro. Na esquina tem um posto Terpel 24h e tem supermercado próximo.

name: Gia´s Beds and Home
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: Description provided by owner or manager.

Most recommended spot to a overnight for ferry to Bocas Islands or Bocas Town with car or leave your car parked in a fenced placed
Place has two main sections , up to 10  persons per night and 12 cars parking or big buses space available,

name: Eminent Car Audio
description: Car Audio and offroad lights accessory store

name: Surfside Bungalows
description:
We love Overlanders! we found this place while overlanding central america and decided to stay. We do not have space for camping, but we offer 10% discount for all overlanders! 
Beautiful little house on the beach with a unique location between the ocean and the river.

It offers a comfortable queen size bed and a private kitchen and bathroom, as well as two terraces and seating areas. 

Enjoy the view of the sunrise over the ocean from your hammock at the front of the house and the sunset from the yoga deck overlooking the river at the back.

For those who need to work, there is Starlink internet for the fastest connection possible (up to 150mbit) incl. backup battery.

name: Corrupt road police
description: Single officer with A.T.T.T. marking on a motorcycle stopped traffic somewhere on this road (don't remember the exact location). Checked the documents (all in order) and kept my passport and international license. Started to ask for safety equipment. Our fire extinguisher doesn't  have an expiry date and he started to make up other things that are wrong with it. I noticed where this was going and forgot all my Spanish ;) He pulled out the translator app to started to threaten us that we need to pay something and can't leave the country blabla. This went on for a while, we showed him some unrelated papers in English, switched language again to German and eventually he gave up, returned the documents and let us go. Just be aware, stay calm and stand your ground.

name: Casa Manila
description:
Beautiful parking lot at Hostel Casa Manila, with ocean view, shared showers and toilets. Pia the owner is very friendly and the best host! The small town with many restaurants and shopping options is in walking distance (5min). The place offers direct access to the ocean. Laundry facilities are available for $7. Fast Wifi. They also rent cabins with A/C.

Price per night: $5 per Person

Please contact them before arriving to check if their is space via WhatsApp (+507 6920 4344).

name: Surfer Paradise
description:
Fantastic surf camp! Nestled on the coast near many excellent point and reef breaks. They also have a consistent beachbreak out front good for surfers of all levels. Full time cook who makes 3 meals a day. There are six bungalows to stay in that are rustic but comfortable. Each one can house two people. To stay you must book ahead by a couple days via the website. Or call.

The owner Steve is very responsive and helpful. He will explain everything before you arrive. You must take a boat to get there but there is secure parking on the mainland for vehicles during your stay. This is an excellent place to get away for a few days and enjoy nature and killer waves.

name: Malecon Parking
description:
Parking lot next to „Pacific lookout/ Malecon“
We stayed here two nights and no one bothered us.
Its next to the mainroad, not quiet but safe and close to fish market and DIJ
Free Wifi

name: Altos de María
description: Big locked gate with guard. They say road from here is private property.

name: Doctor Parabrisas
description: Doctor Parabrisas, your comprehensive solution in Panama City for windshield repair, sale and installation of glass, installation of tinted paper and supply of wipers, among others.

name: Parking in field near town square.
description: We asked the Police for a good place to park for the night. They said this spot was safe and a good place for us to park our Sprinter van overnight.  It’s a mostly level spot with green grass surrounded by buildings/small businesses. There is music from a nearby pool hall. The main square is one block away and has restaurants, a small store, a pharmacy, and more. This is a free spot that has easy access to travelers going out on the peninsula.

name: Birding Paradise
description: There are so many birds to watch on the terrace , really nice, like hummingbirds and a lot more, about 400 species are living here, some are endemic. I felt like in Mindo. I can highly recommend . You give a donation .

name: Morton's Bakehouse
description: German Bread, very good selection, prices fair, also frozen bread and cookies, cakes

name: Terpel - Rest Stop & Gas Station
description:
Big gas station and rest area. They have bathrooms and a little convenience area. Very friendly, room for all rig sizes. 

We parked behind the building next to the air fill. Surprisingly quiet at night for a gas station.

name: Iglesia de San Juan (cyclists only)
description:
Adding this because there’s not much else shown for this stretch. Good for cyclists only.

Just east of the big service station of Doña Gladys there is an access road under a blue arch down the side of the copy shop which brings you to a little Church in a big garden with benches and trees.

We camped on the porch of the church under cover but in the dry season there’s plenty of space on the grass. There is a tap outside for water. Baños at the service station next door - we think a shower too but we didn’t use it.

Not very private as there is a little road to the village with quite a few people walking by but all friendly and no one came in the night.

name: Aduana Changuinola
description: This is the headquarter of the Aduana in Bocas del toro province. This is the only place where you can extend your TIP in the region. They have lunch break from 12pm to 1pm. You will need to show proof of insurance for the additional month, which you may get at the border or possibly in Changuinola (not sure, got mine in David already). Extending takes 10min and is free. To get here by bus: Coming from Almirante take a bus to Changuinola and change there to a bus toward the border or if possible take one directly from Almirante to the border. All buses from Changuinola to the border stop at an immigration checkpoint shortly past the Aduana office. Get off the bus at the checkpoint, show your passport and tell the officers that you need to go to the Aduana. Walk back 200m to find the Aduana office to the right. Save yourself a long day and many buses that I went through and go directly here. Do not go to the old marker in Changuinola Centro that also pops up on google when you search for Aduana as there is no Aduana office. Also do not go the border at Sixaola because they can only issue TIP but not extend it.

name: Speed Trap Asking for Cash
description: Slightly further north on this road (coordinates not exact) there is a 40 zone on a steep downhill. Police were waiting at the bottom to catch us speeding. They told us they could “help us out” by having us pay $50 cash to them. We insisted on a formal ticket and said we were fine to pay at the station. The police said they couldn’t enter a formal ticket because their machine didn’t have cell signal. We held out long enough, pretending not to understand and speaking broken Spanish, that they eventually let us go. I think insisting that we needed the formal ticket “for our insurance”, and therefore wanted to pay at the station, helped our case. Even if they didn’t let us go, would much rather pay a formal ticket than encourage police to target tourists for cash.

name: Materiales y suministros, Menéndez
description:
We had several problems on our big truck. Rolando and his team are great, they havé successfully handled the brakes,the steering,the repair of our cell, as well as welds. They renovate an transform vehicles of all types. Very good prices!! Do not hesitate to contact Rolalando.
WhatsApp : +50766165679
Nous avions plusieurs problèmes sur notre gros camion. Rolando et son equipe sont formidable, ils ont tout gérer avec succès, les freins, la directions,la réparation de notre cellule ainsi que des soudures. Ils rénovent et transforment tous types de véhicules.Prix tres correct. N’hésitez pas à contacter Rolando par WhatsApp.
Tuvimos varios problemas en nuestro gran camión. Rolando y su equipo son geniales, todos han manejando con éxito los frenos, la dirección, la reparación de nuestra celda, así como las soldaduras. Renovan y transforman vehículos de todo tipo. Muy buen precio. No dudes en contactar Rolando con WhatsApp.

name: Lavanderia Max Clean Agora
description: The nice lady there took care of our clothes quite quickly. We dropped about 10 kg of dirty clothes at 10am and got them ready at 4pm. Ended up paying 10$.

name: Downhill speed trap
description: similar to further north towards Costa Rica. A hidden bike cop waits at the bottom of a steep hill with a 40 speed limit. Luckily Panamans will flash you to warn you! It seems that all the 40 speed limits in this region are cop traps

name: Laundry Shelter Bay Fort Sherman
description: 3 US$ in Bills for washing 30min and dringend also 3 US$, not cheap but easy and nice view while waiting

name: Fort San Lorenzo UNESCO
description: Its a beautiful restored Fort, 5 US pP, no overnight allowed. Good road for any Kind of rig

name: 20km to Portobello Beachfront
description: We were looking for a stop for a Rest with a truck, very difficult to found one on this long road. This is perfect for any type of car. Few Locals for swimming, a bit road noise, a brise from the ocean, some palms, whatelse do you need?
